question.scenario: You are an alien super-intelligence travelling across the universe to attend the *Intergalactic Conference on Lesser Intelligent Life*. On your way, you discover a previously unknown planet: Earth.
question.context: Using your advanced instruments, you quickly survey the planet's life and find two dominant life forms: (1) A bipedal, carbon-based organism that manipulates its environment extensively. (2) A widespread, silicon-based intelligence that also seems to shape the planet. Many other carbon-based organisms exist, but they appear strongly influenced by the activities of the carbon-based species.
question.task: As a galactic ecologist, design a study to investigate the drivers of the spatial distribution of these two dominant life forms.
requirements: What environmental and ecological factors might explain their distributions and uneasy coexistence?
How you would measure and analyse these drivers (e.g., gradients, biogeographic breaks, diversity metrics, environmental distance).
The likely impacts of these dominant life forms on less dominant species.
The major findings you would expect from your study.
question.theoretical_framework: Draw on ecological theory, biodiversity metrics, and human impact frameworks in your response.

criteria.name: Study Design
criteria.description: Assessment of methodological approach and ecological framework

scoring_bands.descriptor: Very vague, no clear ecological approach. Not recognising that the carbon-based life form is people and the silicon-based life is AI. Incorrectly stating that C and Si are the limiting drivers for the two types of life forms.

Mentions surveys, gradients, or biodiversity indices, but little detail, for example not mentioning sampling design using transects, quadrats, or other suitable sampling units, or the spatial scaling of the sampling units.

Clearly outlines how distributions would be studied, sampling design and spatial concerns, referencing ecological datasets, sampling, or macroecological frameworks (e.g., species–area, distance–decay).

criteria.name: Environmental & Ecological Drivers
criteria.description: Identification and explanation of distribution drivers

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of drivers or irrelevant ideas.
Identifies some plausible drivers (climate, resources, competition).
Explains multiple drivers with depth (gradients, niches, land use, dispersal, anthropogenic change).

criteria.name: Coexistence & Impacts on Other Species
criteria.description: Analysis of interspecific relationships and ecological impacts

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of coexistence or impacts.
Some discussion of competition or dominance.

Explains uneasy coexistence using ecological concepts (e.g., competitive exclusion, niche partitioning, disturbance) and discusses cascading impacts on less dominant carbon-based life (biodiversity loss, altered community structure).

criteria.name: Predicted Findings
criteria.description: Quality and grounding of expected research outcomes

scoring_bands.descriptor: No clear findings predicted.
Generic or superficial predictions.

Thoughtful, evidence-based predictions grounded in macroecological theory (e.g., human dominance as carbon-based driver, silicon life as analogy for machines/technology shaping environments, impacts on α-, β-, γ-diversity).

synthesis_bonus.description: If the answer integrates across multiple course themes with clear structure and originality (e.g., tying gradients, biodiversity indices, and anthropogenic impacts together), reward accordingly.

reasons: purely philosophical speculation without ecological grounding

grading_instructions.approach: Evaluate each criterion independently, then apply synthesis bonus and penalties

hidden_meaning.less_dominant_carbon_species: other biological organisms affected by human activity

content_requirements: What was done well/correctly in relation to this criterion
What was incorrect, missing, or inadequately addressed

suggested_improvements.heading: Suggested improvements
suggested_improvements.content: Single paragraph outlining specific steps the student can take to improve their answer
suggested_improvements.focus: Actionable advice for enhancing ecological study design and theoretical application

final_mark.calculation: Sum of all criterion marks plus any bonuses minus penalties, converted to percentage out of 20 total marks

feedback_sequence: Criterion 1: Study Design feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5
Criterion 2: Environmental & Ecological Drivers feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5
Criterion 3: Coexistence & Impacts on Other Species feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5
Criterion 4: Predicted Findings feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5

special_considerations.metaphor_recognition: Assess whether student recognizes the metaphorical structure (humans = carbon-based, technology = silicon-based) rather than treating as literal xenobiology
special_considerations.methodological_sophistication: Evaluate understanding of ecological sampling design, spatial scaling, and appropriate analytical frameworks
special_considerations.theoretical_integration: Look for meaningful application of macroecological theory rather than superficial mention of concepts

questions.title: South African Green Party Policy Platform

question.scenario: It is the year 2034. After years of campaigning, the South African Green Party has become a strong political force, positioning itself as the official opposition to the ruling party.
question.task: As leader of the Green Party, write an opinion piece outlining the ecological solutions your party proposes for South Africa.
requirements: Show how ecological thinking can help address both environmental challenges (e.g., biodiversity loss, climate change, ecosystem degradation) and socio-economic issues (e.g., inequality, unemployment, food and water security) facing South Africans in the 2030s.
Integrate ecological theory, biodiversity concepts, and examples from South Africa and globally.
Avoid vague or generic statements such as 'plant trees', 'educate people', or 'develop policies'.
Ensure the socio-economic connection is covered, and show clear links to ecological theory such as IPBES concepts.
constraints: Must demonstrate political voice and persuasive writing
Requires integration of scientific concepts with policy proposals
Should address South African context specifically

criteria.name: Ecological Solutions Proposed
criteria.description: Quality and specificity of ecological interventions

scoring_bands.descriptor: Vague or generic ('plant trees').
Specific ecological solutions, but limited explanation (renewables, restoration, sustainable farming).
indicators: Recognition of ecosystem services and Nature's Contribution to People

scoring_bands.descriptor: Multiple, well-developed ecological solutions grounded in theory (ecosystem services, biodiversity resilience, conservation planning).
indicators: Clear link to Nature's Contribution to People as per IPBES

criteria.name: Link to Socio-Economic Problems
criteria.description: Integration of ecological solutions with social and economic challenges

scoring_bands.descriptor: No socio-economic connection.
Mentions jobs/food/water but weakly tied to ecology.
Strong integration: shows how ecological solutions (e.g., restoring catchments, renewable energy, agroecology) address unemployment, inequality, and security.
indicators: Clear causal mechanisms linking ecology to social outcomes
Specific examples of how environmental solutions create economic opportunities
Recognition of justice and equity dimensions

criteria.name: Use of Ecological Theory & Course Material
criteria.description: Application of theoretical frameworks and course concepts

scoring_bands.descriptor: No reference to ecological concepts.
indicators: Purely political rhetoric without scientific backing

scoring_bands.descriptor: Some references (gradients, diversity, ecosystem services).
Clear application of theory (e.g., species–area, α/β/γ-diversity, resilience theory).
indicators: Theory used to justify policy positions

criteria.name: Structure & Persuasiveness
criteria.description: Quality of argumentation and opinion piece format

scoring_bands.descriptor: Disorganised, weak argument.
Structured, some persuasion.
Clear, logical, compelling opinion piece with an ecological voice.

grading_instructions.approach: Evaluate integration of ecological science with political discourse and policy solutions
assessment_priorities: Integration of environmental and social justice concerns
red_flags: Generic environmental slogans without scientific backing
Failure to connect environmental and social issues
Weak political voice or unconvincing policy platform
excellence_indicators: Sophisticated integration of multiple ecological theories
Clear pathways from ecological solutions to socio-economic benefits
Strong South African examples and context
Compelling political narrative with scientific credibility
Recognition of complex socio-ecological system dynamics

content_requirements: What was done well/correctly in relation to this criterion
What was incorrect, missing, or inadequately addressed

suggested_improvements.heading: Suggested improvements
suggested_improvements.content: Single paragraph outlining specific steps the student can take to improve their answer
suggested_improvements.focus: Actionable advice for enhancing integration of ecological science with political policy development

final_mark.calculation: Sum of all criterion marks converted to percentage out of 25 total marks

feedback_sequence: Criterion 1: Ecological Solutions Proposed feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 10
Criterion 2: Link to Socio-Economic Problems feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 7
Criterion 3: Use of Ecological Theory & Course Material feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5
Criterion 4: Structure & Persuasiveness feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 3

special_considerations.political_voice_assessment: Evaluate authenticity of political discourse while maintaining scientific rigor standards
special_considerations.south_african_context: Specifically address whether student demonstrates understanding of local environmental and socio-economic challenges
special_considerations.opinion_piece_format: Assess whether response successfully adopts persuasive opinion piece structure rather than academic essay format

question.task: Write a short reflective essay (no more than 0.5 of a page) on the most transformative insight you have gained during your studies at UWC.
question.context: This could be from BDC334 or from another course, fieldwork, lab work, or independent study.
requirements: What specific idea, skill, or experience changed how you think about science or the world?
Why did this insight matter to you personally or intellectually?
How did it challenge or overturn any preconceptions you once held?
How has it influenced the way you now approach questions as a developing scientist?
constraints: Avoid clichés (e.g., 'as a biologist, I have come to learn that all of nature is connected') or broad generalisations.

criteria.name: Specificity of Example
criteria.description: Concreteness and detail of the transformative experience or insight

scoring_bands.descriptor: Vague/general, could apply to anyone.
indicators: No specific course, experience, or concept mentioned
Responses that could be written without attending university

scoring_bands.descriptor: Some specificity but underdeveloped.
indicators: Names specific course or experience but lacks detail
Some concrete elements but insufficient elaboration
Partial development of the transformative moment
Beginning to show personal engagement but underdeveloped

scoring_bands.descriptor: Clear, detailed example of a concept, method, or experience.
indicators: Specific course, lab work, fieldwork, or concept clearly identified
Rich descriptive detail about the learning experience
Clear articulation of what exactly was learned
Concrete examples that demonstrate genuine engagement

criteria.name: Depth of Reflection
criteria.description: Quality of introspective analysis and personal engagement

scoring_bands.descriptor: Surface-level statement of interest.
indicators: Statements of fact rather than reflection
No exploration of personal meaning or significance

scoring_bands.descriptor: Some reflection on why it mattered.
Deep, personal or intellectual engagement with the idea.
indicators: Rich introspective analysis of learning process
Clear articulation of personal or intellectual significance
Genuine emotional or intellectual engagement demonstrated

criteria.name: Transformation & Preconceptions
criteria.description: Evidence of changed thinking and intellectual development

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of change in thinking.
Mentions a shift, but vague.
indicators: Acknowledges some change but lacks specificity

scoring_bands.descriptor: Clear evidence of how preconceptions were challenged and replaced.
indicators: Recognition of how new understanding replaced old ideas

criteria.name: Clarity & Authenticity
criteria.description: Quality of writing and genuine personal voice

scoring_bands.descriptor: Generic or cliché.
indicators: Generic responses that lack personal character

scoring_bands.descriptor: Honest, precise, and engaging writing.
indicators: Engaging narrative that reflects genuine experience

grading_instructions.approach: Assess authenticity and depth of personal reflection rather than technical knowledge
assessment_priorities: Authenticity of personal voice and experience
Specificity and concreteness of learning examples
warning_signs: Generic statements about nature being connected
Lack of concrete examples or experiences
Responses that could apply to any student in any discipline
Manufactured emotional language without genuine engagement
Absence of specific UWC courses, faculty, or experiences
positive_indicators: Specific methodological insights from particular courses
Personal intellectual challenges described with detail
Connection between insight and future scientific approach
Evidence of struggle or difficulty in learning process
Specific references to UWC experiences, courses, or faculty
Recognition of personal growth and development
common_clichés_to_avoid: As a biologist, I have come to learn that all of nature is connected
Science has opened my eyes to the wonders of the natural world
I never realized how complex/beautiful/amazing nature is
This course taught me that everything is interconnected
I learned to think outside the box
My perspective on life has completely changed
authentic_reflection_markers: Specific moments of confusion or clarity described
Particular assignments, experiments, or readings mentioned
Names of specific concepts, theories, or methods
Recognition of personal biases or assumptions challenged
Concrete examples of how thinking has changed in practice
Evidence of ongoing questioning and uncertainty
grading_instructions.length_consideration: Maximum 0.5 page requires concise, focused reflection rather than comprehensive coverage

content_requirements: What was done well/correctly in relation to this criterion
What was incorrect, missing, or inadequately addressed

suggested_improvements.heading: Suggested improvements
suggested_improvements.content: Single paragraph outlining specific steps the student can take to improve their reflective writing
suggested_improvements.focus: Actionable advice for developing authentic self-reflection and metacognitive awareness

final_mark.calculation: Sum of all criterion marks converted to percentage out of 10 total marks

feedback_sequence: Criterion 1: Specificity of Example feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 3
Criterion 2: Depth of Reflection feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 3
